text: it's tragic it's sad but it's not a
surprise Cynthia Thomas says it came as
no surprise when major nidal malik hasan
recently gunned down dozens of soldiers
on a military base in Fort Hood Texas
she runs under the hood cafe a private
assistant center for soldiers in Killeen
Texas she helps those suffering from
post-traumatic stress disorder buying
private counseling when the military
fails to assist them we have been sane
and warning and trying to get bring this
to people's attention that something
like this was eventually going to happen
and very very soon but nobody paid
attention nobody listened and the most
tragic part is that it could have been
prevented in recent days army officials
have pledged to redouble their efforts
to help soldiers cope with deployment as
well as helping them with goal setting
skills upon their return a crisis center
in Fort Hood is averaging 60 phone calls
a week from soldiers and family members
seeking help for problems in July
Lieutenant General Rick Lynch then the
base commander told Congress he
desperately needed more mental health
professionals
Michael Kern a 22 year old private first
class from Riverside California said he
tried unsuccessfully to obtain help for
stress last year in Baghdad I was afraid
to approach my chain of command as I
approached him two times before while I
was in Iraq about my mental health
problems and one time they told me a it
would go away just you know it'll be
fine you'll be fine don't worry about it
it didn't one day on my birthday
actually they gave me the day off they
all rolled it on a mission I got to stay
back I told one person in confidence
that hey I'm going to mental health just
to get checked out I'm not trying to get
out of work or anything I just I need to
talk to someone and when I came back my
whole platoon was like making fun of me
ultimately which is the most surprising
part that people need to know is when
they do see a doctor and the doctor
recommends that he goes to the Warrior
Transition brigade or anything else the
doctor is it's only a recommendation
ultimately their command makes that
decision mm-hmm so you're looking at a
captain that could be 25 years old with
you know not that much life experience
mmm you know making a decision over a
doctor interviews with soldiers who have
deployed one or more times to Iraq or
Afghanistan show that the Army's efforts
are still falling short and after
Michaels return to the United States his
problems intensified so I saw help off
post and was seeing a psychiatrist off
post she convinced me that I needed to
you know go and get help through the
military that something was seriously
wrong with me she diagnosed me with PTSD
and TBI and all that stuff so I
approached the military in a very you
know covert kind of way
and they gave me an appointment for two
months out from the day I told him two
months between that time I had a mental
breakdown I was seeing people that I
shot in Iraq i was here at under the
hood cafe some of the soldiers here knew
i was having problems they took me to
the ER and I did impatient i'm in the
psych ward i'm no longer allowed to be
in a combat stress environment simulated
combat environment not allowed to have
guns I'm not I can barely do anything
all I'm really allowed to do in the
military is walk and talk
